   Assessment and Plan
    74-F w/ HTN, HL, hypothyroidism, and recent dx of adenocarcinoma, most
   likely ovarian primary, who presented to the ED for evaluation of acute
   renal failure and hyperkalemia.  Noted to have pleural and pericardial
   effusions.
   #. Hypotension- Has required Levophed for much of admission.
   -Concerned for sepsis as has tachy, leukocytosis and on pressors
   - started empiric vanc, zosyn, cipro to cover HAP as this most likely
   given poor pulmonary status.
   - Antibiotics will also cover line infections. Need to change both HD
   cath and art line
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim wnl so likely not adrenally insufficient.
   - Consulted endo regarding hypothyroidism as cause of hypotension
   - Vigileo suggested intravascular depletion.
   - Intravascular volume repletion with crystalloid and colloid as needed
   #. Acute renal failure - Pt p/w weakness and SOB, found to have ARF w/
   Cr 7.8. Seen by renal in [**Name (NI) 73**], unclear baseline Cr for comparison but
   impressively sick. DDx includes pre-renal physiology [**2-22**] poor PO intake
   in combination with an increased dose of Lasix, contrast-induced
   nephropathy (however, significant time delay between CT scan-[**9-5**] and
   first lab results showing elev Cr), and post-obstructive renal failure
   from R hydronephrosis (?) [**2-22**] tumor burden vs. ascites as seen US o/n.
   Seen by renal in ED, who felt no emergent need for HD.
   - CVVH started on [**9-16**] and had to be held as line is no longer
   working.  [**Month (only) 51**] be able to transition to HD vs d/c dialysis all together
   - Will likely need new HD line placed and this will likely require IR
   as this was needed for last line.
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   - D/c renagel as phos is 2.4
   - Will obtain new u/a and urine culture.  Re-imaged kidneys with non
   contrast CT
    - If it is decided that pt needs a perc nephrostomy will re-consult
   uro (they had been consulted when first admitted and it was decided to
   hold
   # Adenocarcinoma, most likely ovarian
   - Cytology consistent with an adenocarcinoma. Staining revealed CK7
   positive only with rare B72.3 cells positive.  Equivocal for ovarian vs
   lung but morphology is consistent with ovarian.  Heme no longer feels
   it is necessary to obtain further tissue sample.  Will not require a
   lymph node biopsy
   # SOB and pleural effusion- improved s/p pigtail placement. Now on NC
   only.
   - Pigtail catheter in L base draining wel1 and pt more comfortable and
   off BiPAP.
   - IP will see pt tomorrow  morning to help flush tube (although it is
   still draining freely) as well as determine need for wall suction vs
   water seal.  Also, per IP, obtained non contrast CT for further eval.
   - Pleural effusion was malignant
   - ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion. Repeat ECHO
   "unchanged".  If pt continues to require pressors, will repeat echo.
   Depending on what echo shows in terms of the RV, will eval need for a
   V/Q scan to r/o PE.
   - Added standing bronchodilators
   #. Hyperkalemia - Most likely [**2-22**] worsening acute renal failure, esp in
   setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and ACE-I.
   Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Now s/p tx w/ Ca
   gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.
   - Change from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and recently diagnosed adenocarcinoma, most likely ovarian primary. She was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of acute renal failure and hyperkalemia.

The patient has been requiring norepinephrine infusion for hypotension, and her condition is complicated by pleural and pericardial effusions. She has also developed acute renal failure, and her creatinine level is 1.5 mg/dL. The differential diagnosis includes pre-renal physiology, poor PO intake, contrast-induced nephropathy, and post-obstructive renal failure.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics to cover hospital-acquired pneumonia and line infections. She has also been started on intravenous fluids and colloid to treat intravascular depletion. The patient's potassium level has responded to treatment, and her thyroid function tests indicate hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her hypotension.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's tachycardia, leukocytosis, and requirement for pressors suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and her condition is complicated by acute renal failure.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's pleural effusion and requirement for BiPAP suggest the possibility of respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion and requirement for pressors suggest the possibility of cardiac tamponade.
5. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's hypercoagulability and requirement for prophylactic heparin suggest the possibility of venous thromboembolism.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her hypotension and other symptoms.
7. Adenocarcinoma progression: The patient's recent diagnosis of adenocarcinoma may be progressing, which could worsen her symptoms and reduce her quality of life.

The patient's care plan should include ongoing monitoring of her vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies. She should continue to receive antibiotics to cover hospital-acquired pneumonia and line infections. Her thyroid function should be re-checked in several days to ensure that her hypothyroidism is being adequately treated. The patient's dialysis catheter and PICC line should be monitored for signs of infection or malfunction. Her respiratory status should be closely monitored, and she should be treated for respiratory failure if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with shock of uncertain etiology, recent diagnosis of ovarian cancer, and multiple comorbidities. She has been in the ICU for several days, and her condition has been unstable. She has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and diuretics, but her blood pressure and heart rate remain unstable.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalance, and hypothyroidism. Her chest x-ray shows a small effusion, and her echocardiogram shows a small effusion without signs of tamponade. Her cortisol levels are normal, ruling out adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, and she is receiving oxygen therapy. Her nutritional status is adequate, and she is receiving regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's rising white count and hypotension suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating acute kidney injury, which could worsen if not managed properly.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH and FT4 levels suggest hypothyroidism, which could contribute to her shock and other systemic symptoms.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but she may be at risk for respiratory failure if her condition worsens.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure and heart rate remain unstable, which could lead to cardiovascular instability and organ dysfunction.
6. Infection: The patient's rising white count and hypotension suggest the possibility of infection, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
7. Ovarian cancer progression: The patient's ovarian cancer diagnosis is a significant risk factor for complications, including disease progression and metastasis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely.
2. Manage the patient's sepsis and acute kidney injury aggressively with antibiotics, vasopressors, and diuretics as needed.
3. Treat the patient's hypothyroidism with intravenous replacement therapy.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
5. Consider consulting a cardiologist to manage the patient's cardiovascular instability.
6. Discuss the patient's infection risk with the healthcare team and consider implementing infection prevention measures.
7. Consider consulting a gynecologic oncologist to manage the patient's ovarian cancer diagnosis and potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with shock of uncertain etiology, recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer. She is receiving treatment for shock, including empiric antibiotics, and has been on vasopressors. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her shock. She also has acute renal failure, and a dialysis line change is being discussed. The patient has a pleural effusion, which is being managed with a pigtail catheter.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's rising white count is concerning for possible infection, which could worsen her shock and lead to septicemia.
2. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her shock and could worsen if not treated properly.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure could worsen if not managed properly, leading to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Pleural Effusion: The patient's pleural effusion could worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory distress and decreased lung function.
5. Sepsis: The patient's shock and rising white count could lead to sepsis, which could worsen her condition and lead to multi-organ failure.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's shock could lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
7. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory distress could worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory failure.
8. Nutritional Complications: The patient's poor nutritional status could worsen if not managed properly, leading to malnutrition and decreased immune function.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's shock could lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
10. Psychological Complications: The patient's critical illness could lead to psychological complications, such as anxiety, depression, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

   CT ([**9-22**]):
   Left lung re-expansion
   Increase right pleural effusion with collapse of RLL
   No change in right hydronephrosis
   Assessment and Plan
    74-F w/ HTN, HL, hypothyroidism, and recent dx of adenocarcinoma, most
   likely ovarian primary, who presented to the ED for evaluation of acute
   renal failure and hyperkalemia.  Noted to have pleural and pericardial
   effusions.
   74
R w/ metastatic ovarian cancer, ARF, diffuse LAD, pulm nodules, and
   pleural effusion.  Course has been complicated by hypotension requiring
   pressors.
   #. Hypotension- Has required Levophed for much of admission.
   -Concerned for sepsis as has tachy, leukocytosis and on pressors
   - started empiric vanc, zosyn, cipro to cover HAP as this most likely
   given poor pulmonary status.
   - Antibiotics will also cover line infections. Need to change both HD
   cath and art line
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim wnl so likely not adrenally insufficient.
   - Consulted endo regarding hypothyroidism as cause of hypotension
   - Vigileo suggested intravascular depletion.
   - Intravascular volume repletion with crystalloid and colloid as needed
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology c/w malignancy.  Improved s/p
   pigtail placement. Now on NC only.
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  270cc serosang fluid in prev 24 hours.
   - IP following pigtail.
   - Pleurodesis when stable
   - ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion. Repeat ECHO
   "unchanged".  If pt continues to require pressors, will repeat echo.
   Depending on what echo shows in terms of the RV, will eval need for a
   V/Q scan to r/o PE.
   - Added standing bronchodilators
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.
   - Line replaced by renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   - D/c renagel as phos is 2.4
   - Will obtain new u/a and urine culture.  Re-imaged kidneys with non
   contrast CT
    - If it is decided that pt needs a perc nephrostomy will re-consult
   uro (they had been consulted when first admitted and it was decided to
   hold
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - Will require inpt palliatice chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   #. Hyperkalemia - Most likely [**2-22**] worsening acute renal failure, esp in
   setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and ACE-I.
   Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Now s/p tx w/ Ca
   gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.
   - Change from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   ICU Care

   Assessment and Plan
    74-F w/ HTN, HL, hypothyroidism, and recent dx of adenocarcinoma, most
   likely ovarian primary, who presented to the ED for evaluation of acute
   renal failure and hyperkalemia.  Noted to have pleural and pericardial
   effusions.
   74
R w/ metastatic ovarian cancer, ARF, diffuse LAD, pulm nodules, and
   pleural effusion.  Course has been complicated by hypotension requiring
   pressors.
   #. Hypotension- Has required Levophed for much of admission.
   -Concerned for sepsis as has tachy, leukocytosis and on pressors
   - started empiric vanc, zosyn, cipro to cover HAP as this most likely
   given poor pulmonary status.
   - Antibiotics will also cover line infections. Need to change both HD
   cath and art line
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim wnl so likely not adrenally insufficient.
   - Consulted endo regarding hypothyroidism as cause of hypotension
   - Vigileo suggested intravascular depletion.
   - Intravascular volume repletion with crystalloid and colloid as needed
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology c/w malignancy.  Improved s/p
   pigtail placement. Now on NC only.
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  270cc serosang fluid in prev 24 hours.
   - IP following pigtail.
   - Pleurodesis when stable
   - ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion. Repeat ECHO
   "unchanged".  If pt continues to require pressors, will repeat echo.
   Depending on what echo shows in terms of the RV, will eval need for a
   V/Q scan to r/o PE.
   - Added standing bronchodilators
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.
   - Line replaced by renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   - D/c renagel as phos is 2.4
   - Will obtain new u/a and urine culture.  Re-imaged kidneys with non
   contrast CT
    - If it is decided that pt needs a perc nephrostomy will re-consult
   uro (they had been consulted when first admitted and it was decided to
   hold
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer
   - Will require inpt palliatice chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   #. Hyperkalemia - Most likely [**2-22**] worsening acute renal failure, esp in
   setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and ACE-I.
   Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Now s/p tx w/ Ca
   gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.
   - Change from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and recent diagnosis of metastatic ovarian cancer. She was admitted to the ICU with acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and bilateral pleural effusions. She has required pressors to maintain blood pressure and has been treated with antibiotics to cover possible infections. She has also been started on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and has had a pigtail catheter placed to drain the pleural effusions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's tachycardia, leukocytosis, and requirement for pressors increase the risk of sepsis.
2. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary nodules increase the risk of PE.
3. Tamponade: The patient's small effusion in the right ventricle and the need for pressors to maintain blood pressure increase the risk of tamponade.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure and requirement for CVVH increase the risk of chronic kidney disease and the need for dialysis.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia and requirement for medications to control potassium levels increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism and requirement for medication to control thyroid function increase the risk of hypothyroidism-related complications, such as fatigue, weakness, and depression.
7. Metastatic Cancer: The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer and requirement for palliative chemotherapy increase the risk of cancer-related complications, such as pain, bleeding, and infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels, including potassium, sodium, and magnesium.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function, including creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels.
4. Consider ordering a V/Q scan to rule out PE.
5. Consider ordering an echocardiogram to evaluate the patient's cardiac function and rule out tamponade.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusions and consider repeating the CT scan to evaluate the extent of the effusions.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider ordering a chest X-ray to evaluate for signs of pneumonia.
8. Consider ordering a urine culture to evaluate for signs of infection.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider ordering a nutrition consult to evaluate the patient's nutritional needs.
10. Consider ordering a consult with a palliative care specialist to evaluate the patient's symptoms and provide supportive care.

    74-F w/ HTN, HL, hypothyroidism, and recent dx of adenocarcinoma, most

   -Concerned for sepsis as has tachy, leukocytosis and on pressors

   - Vigileo suggested intravascular depletion.
   - Intravascular volume repletion with crystalloid and colloid as needed
   #. Acute renal failure - Pt p/w weakness and SOB, found to have ARF w/
   Cr 7.8. Seen by renal in [**Name (NI) 73**], unclear baseline Cr for comparison but
   impressively sick. DDx includes pre-renal physiology [**2-22**] poor PO intake
   in combination with an increased dose of Lasix, contrast-induced
   nephropathy (however, significant time delay between CT scan-[**9-5**] and
   first lab results showing elev Cr), and post-obstructive renal failure
   from R hydronephrosis (?) [**2-22**] tumor burden vs. ascites as seen US o/n.

   - CVVH started on [**9-16**] and had to be held as line is no longer

   positive only with rare B72.3 cells positive.  Equivocal for ovarian vs
   lung but morphology is consistent with ovarian.  Heme no longer feels
   it is necessary to obtain further tissue sample.  Will not require a
   lymph node biopsy
   # SOB and pleural effusion- improved s/p pigtail placement. Now on NC
   only.
   - Pigtail catheter in L base draining wel1 and pt more comfortable and
   off BiPAP.
   - IP will see pt tomorrow  morning to help flush tube (although it is
   still draining freely) as well as determine need for wall suction vs
   water seal.  Also, per IP, obtained non contrast CT for further eval.
   - Pleural effusion was malignant
   - ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion. Repeat ECHO
   "unchanged".  If pt continues to require pressors, will repeat echo.
   Depending on what echo shows in terms of the RV, will eval need for a
   V/Q scan to r/o PE.
   - Added standing bronchodilators
   #. Hyperkalemia - Most likely [**2-22**] worsening acute renal failure, esp in
   setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and ACE-I.

   gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.

   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to address her multiple medical complications.

 shock.  Has required Levophed for much of

   vanc.  Abx also would have covered a line infection.  Changed HD cath

ed.  Will monitor PICC line
   for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal insufficiency.
   Consulted ID for evaluation of whether hypothyroidism could cause
   shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid and transitioned to IV but

   - Cardiogenic-  ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion.
   Repeat ECHO reported that it was "unchanged".  Will repeat TTE today to
   again eval for tamponade.  Depending on what echo shows in terms of the

   - Will require inpt palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum

   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome

 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.
   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and
   ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/
   Ca gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment  and has remained

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old woman with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure (ARF), and malignant pleural effusion. She has been in the ICU for several days, requiring pressors to maintain blood pressure, and has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, antihypertensives, and diuretics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.6°C (96.1°F), heart rate of 97 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 121/92 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 99%. She has a leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 248 K/μL, and her platelet count is 248 K/μL.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Serum creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 23 mEq/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.2 mEq/L
* Lactic acid: 2.5 mmol/L
* Ionized calcium: 0.95
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL

The patient has bilateral pleural effusions, with a left-sided effusion that has improved with pigtail catheter placement, but the right-sided effusion has increased. She has also developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with decreased breath sounds and faint expiratory wheezes on the right.

The patient's medical history includes hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. She has been taking medications for these conditions, including thyroid hormone replacement, statins, and antihypertensives.

Based on the patient's condition, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is still unstable, and she may require continued pressors to maintain adequate blood pressure.
2. ARF: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may require continued dialysis to manage her kidney function.
3. Malignant pleural effusion: The patient's right-sided effusion has increased, and she may require further treatment to manage this condition.
4. ARDS: The patient's lung function is compromised, and she may require continued respiratory support to manage her respiratory status.
5. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated white blood cell count suggest that she may be at risk for infection, particularly in the setting of her immunocompromised state.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may require further management, particularly if her symptoms worsen or if her thyroid function tests indicate a need for adjustment in her thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require continued management with statins and other lipid-lowering medications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires continued close monitoring and management to prevent complications and optimize her care.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure (ARF), and malignant pleural effusion. She has been in the ICU for several days and has required pressors to manage hypotension. Her course has been complicated by hypotension, shock, and ARF, which has required continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.6°C (96.1°F), heart rate of 97 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 121/92 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 99% on a nasal cannula.

The patient's physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds bilaterally, faint expiratory wheezes on the right, and 3+ edema without rashes or cyanosis.

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 20.7-21.5 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 28.9-31.5%
* Platelet count: 248 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.5-2.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 34 mg/dL
* Glucose: 96-166 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Ionized calcium: 0.95 mmol/L
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.5 mmol/L
* Total CO2: 28 mmHg

The patient's radiological studies show:

* A CT scan on [**9-22**] reveals left lung re-expansion, increased right pleural effusion with collapse of the right lower lobe, and no change in right hydronephrosis.
* A thoracentesis was performed on [**9-22**], and 270 mL of serosanguinous fluid was drained.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypotension and shock: The patient's hypotension and shock may be due to sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, or hypovolemia. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
2. ARF: The patient's ARF may worsen, and CVVH may need to be continued or adjusted.
3. Malignant pleural effusion: The patient's malignant pleural effusion may continue to worsen, and further interventions, such as pleurodesis, may be necessary.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia has resolved, but monitoring of potassium levels and electrolyte balance is essential to prevent recurrence.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may require further evaluation and treatment, and monitoring of thyroid function tests is necessary.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require continued management and monitoring of lipid levels.
7. Infections: The patient's risk of infection is high due to her immunocompromised state and prolonged hospitalization. Monitoring for signs of infection and prompt treatment are essential.
8. Pulmonary complications: The patient's respiratory status may worsen, and further interventions, such as bronchodilators and oxygen therapy, may be necessary.
9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status may worsen, and further evaluation and treatment may be necessary to manage her cardiogenic shock.

In summary, the patient's health progress in the ICU is complex, and multiple medical complications can arise. Close monitoring and management are essential to prevent complications and improve her outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old woman with shock of uncertain etiology, acute renal failure, and ovarian cancer. The patient has undergone several interventions, including the re-wiring of a line, resumption of CVVH, and changes to medical and family history.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.2°C (97.2°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (93-131 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 104/78 mmHg (84-128/92 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 31 inspirations per minute (16-35 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 98%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination is notable for the following:

* Overweight/obese
* Normocephalic head, ears, nose, and throat
* Diminished right radial pulse, present left radial pulse, and non-assessed right and left digital pulses
* Clear breath sounds in the anterior exam
* Soft, distended abdomen with no tenderness
* Normal tone and movement

Laboratory results are as follows:

* Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 20.7
* Platelet count: 248 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23 mEq/L
* Serum potassium: 4.2 mEq/L
* Serum magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Serum phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 393 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Shock of uncertain etiology, treated empirically while awaiting cultures
* Cortisol results exclude adrenal insufficiency
* Leucocytosis persists
* Thoracentesis today per IP
* Dialysis line changed by renal yesterday
* TSH/FT4 results concerning for hypothyroidism, treated with intravenous replacement therapy
* Respiratory distress, managed with bronchodilation and chest tube management
* Acute renal failure, treated with CVVHD
* Ovarian cancer, to be managed by OMED once acute issues are complete
* Pleural effusion (malignant), managed with a pigtail catheter and eventual pleurodesis or Pleurx

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis secondary to the patient's leucocytosis and empiric antibiotic treatment
* Hypothyroidism exacerbating shock and other symptoms
* Respiratory failure secondary to pleural effusion and respiratory distress
* Acute kidney injury worsening to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease
* Infections related to indwelling lines and catheters
* Hemodynamic instability and shock secondary to hypovolemia, cardiac dysfunction, or vasopressor therapy
* Metabolic derangements, such as hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, or hyperphosphatemia, secondary to acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances.

R w/ metastatic ovarian cancer, ARF on CVVH, and malignant pleural
   effusion.  Course has been complicated by hypotension requiring
   pressors.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and hyperkalemia.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   #. Hypotension
 shock.  Has required Levophed for much of admission.
   Last 2 days been able to tolerate long pressor free periods.
   Differential dx for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes,
   cardiogenic, hypovolemia.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  Continue empiric coverage until cultures
   clear.  Thus far, received 5 days of zosyn, 8 days of cipro, and 3 days
   of vanc.  Abx also would have covered a line infection.  Changed HD
   cath over the wire on [**9-22**] and art line was d/c
ed.  Will monitor PICC
   line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal insufficiency.
   Consulted ID for evaluation of whether hypothyroidism could cause
   shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid and transitioned to IV but
   endocrinology felt that this was unlikely.
   - Cardiogenic-  ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion.
   Repeat ECHO reported that it was "unchanged".  Will repeat TTE today to
   again eval for tamponade.  Depending on what echo shows in terms of the
   RV, will eval need for a V/Q scan to r/o PE as a cause of shock.
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  However, she did not require pressors for
   much of the day.  Will run CVVH at a 0 balance.
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology c/w malignancy.  Left sided
   effusion improved s/p pigtail placement but CT on [**9-22**] showed increased
   right sided effusion.  Only requiring NC at this time.
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  270cc serosang fluid in prev 24 hours.
   - IP following pigtail.
   - IP will also perform thoracentesis of right sided effusion.
   - ? of Pleurodesis when stable
   - Added standing bronchodilators for wheezing
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.
   - Line replaced by renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   Will re-consult urology for percutaneous nephrostomy tube for
   drainage.  [**Month (only) 51**] need anesthesia eval prior to procedure.
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   - Follow electrolytes and replete as needed
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - Will require inpt palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.
   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and
   ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/
   Ca gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment  and has remained
   wnl.
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure (ARF) on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH), and malignant pleural effusion. She has a complicated course with hypotension requiring pressors, and has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, calcium gluconate, and insulin/dextrose. The patient has also undergone various procedures, including thoracentesis, pleurodesis, and placement of a pigtail catheter.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic shock, or hypovolemia. The patient's blood pressure has been stable over the past two days, but it is still a concern.
2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's ARF is likely due to volume overload and anasarca. CVVH has been started, but the patient's right hydronephrosis has not improved, and the patient may require a percutaneous nephrostomy tube for drainage.
3. Malignant Pleural Effusion: The patient has a bilateral pleural effusion, with the left-sided effusion improving after pigtail catheter placement. However, the right-sided effusion has increased, and the patient may require further treatment, including thoracentesis and pleurodesis.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia has resolved with treatment, but it is still a concern, especially given the patient's worsening renal function.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her hypotension, and the patient has been started on a higher dose of thyroid medication.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia is being treated with a statin, but it is still a concern, especially given the patient's underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Re-evaluate the patient's ARF and consider the need for further treatment, including a percutaneous nephrostomy tube.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusion and consider further treatment, including thoracentesis and pleurodesis.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's potassium levels and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to treat the patient's hypothyroidism with a higher dose of thyroid medication.
6. Continue to treat the patient's hyperlipidemia with a statin.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure, and bilateral pleural effusions. She has been admitted to the ICU for several days and has been treated with various medications, including pressors, insulin, and diuretics. Her condition has been complicated by hypotension, hyperkalemia, and hypothyroidism. She has undergone thoracentesis and has had a pigtail catheter placed to drain the pleural effusions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, or hypovolemia. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may be due to volume overload, anasarca, and the medications she is taking, including Lasix and ACE-I. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
3. Bilateral Pleural Effusions: The patient's bilateral pleural effusions may be due to metastatic ovarian cancer. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may be due to the ultrafiltrate bath having a Na concentration of 130. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may be due to the medications she is taking, including insulin and dextrose. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be due to the medications she is taking, including Lasix and ACE-I. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and treat any hypotension that occurs.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her medications as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusions and adjust her medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's hyponatremia and adjust her medications as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperglycemia and adjust her medications as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and adjust her medications as needed.
7. Consider performing a V/Q scan to rule out pulmonary embolism as a cause of hypotension.
8. Consider performing a CT scan to evaluate the patient's kidneys and determine the underlying cause of her acute renal failure.
9. Consider performing a thoracentesis to drain the pleural effusions and evaluate the underlying cause.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust her medications as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure (ARF), and malignant pleural effusion. She has been admitted to the ICU for hypotension, which has required pressors, and has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. Her current medications include insulin, calcium gluconate, and norepinephrine.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 99 bpm, and blood pressure of 93/67 mmHg. Her respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 100% on a nasal cannula. Her physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds bilaterally, faint expiratory wheezes on the right, and 3+ edema without rashes or cyanosis.

Laboratory results show:

* WBC: 21.2
* Hct: 31.5
* Plt: 220
* Cr: 2.1
* Glucose: 96
* Ionized Ca++: 1.12
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 1.8 mg/dL

The patient's pleural fluid analysis shows a pH of 6.99, HCT of 3%, and 600 WBC with 15% polymorphonuclear cells, 2% lymphocytes, 3% monocytes, and 5% macrophages.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, or hypovolemia. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
2. ARF: The patient's ARF may be due to volume overload and anasarca. CVVH has been started, and the patient will require close monitoring of electrolytes and repletion as needed.
3. Malignant pleural effusion: The patient's malignant pleural effusion may require pleurodesis or pleurex.
4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require continued treatment with a statin.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may require further evaluation and treatment with thyroid hormone replacement.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia has been resolved, but close monitoring of electrolytes is needed to prevent recurrence.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but close monitoring is needed to prevent respiratory failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue CVVH to manage ARF and volume overload.
2. Monitor the patient's electrolytes and replete as needed.
3. Evaluate the patient's hypotension further to determine the underlying cause.
4. Consider pleurodesis or pleurex for the malignant pleural effusion.
5. Continue treatment for hyperlipidemia.
6. Monitor the patient's hypothyroidism and consider further evaluation and treatment with thyroid hormone replacement.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely to prevent respiratory failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure, and bilateral pleural effusions. She has been admitted to the ICU for hypotension, requiring pressors, and has a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension, shock, and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has undergone various treatments, including empiric antibiotics, CVVH, and thoracentesis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's echocardiogram showed a small pericardial effusion, but the differential diagnosis for shock includes cardiogenic causes, and the patient's cardiac function is not fully evaluated.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a leukocytosis, and empiric antibiotics have been started to cover for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).
3. Metabolic causes: The patient's hypothyroidism has been increased, and her metabolic status is being monitored.
4. Hypovolemia: The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, and she has been repleted with crystalloid and colloid.
5. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's right-sided pleural effusion has increased, and a V/Q scan may be necessary to rule out PE.
6. Malignant pleural effusion: The patient's pleural effusions are cytology-positive for malignancy, and pleurodesis may be necessary when she is stable.
7. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's AKI is complicated by significant volume overload and anasarca, and CVVH has been restarted.
8. Hyperkalemia: The patient's hyperkalemia has been resolved, but her electrolyte levels are being closely monitored.
9. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient is being treated with allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome.
10. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is being monitored, and her thyroid function is being re-checked in several days.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiopulmonary status, including her blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue empiric antibiotics until cultures clear.
3. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and replete as necessary.
4. Consider a V/Q scan to rule out PE.
5. Consult with oncology regarding the patient's treatment plan, including palliative chemotherapy and potential pleurodesis.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and replete as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust her thyroid medication as necessary.

R w/ metastatic ovarian cancer, ARF on CVVH, and malignant pleural
   effusion.  Course has been complicated by hypotension requiring
   pressors.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and hyperkalemia.  PMH
   includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   #. Hypotension
 shock.  Has required Levophed for much of admission.
   Last 2 days been able to tolerate long pressor free periods.
   Differential dx for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes,
   cardiogenic, hypovolemia.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  Continue empiric coverage until cultures
   clear.  Thus far, received 5 days of zosyn, 8 days of cipro, and 3 days
   of vanc.  Abx also would have covered a line infection.  Changed HD
   cath over the wire on [**9-22**] and art line was d/c
ed.  Will monitor PICC
   line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal insufficiency.
   Consulted ID for evaluation of whether hypothyroidism could cause
   shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid and transitioned to IV but
   endocrinology felt that this was unlikely.
   - Cardiogenic-  ECHO unconvincing for tamponade, just small effusion.
   Repeat ECHO reported that it was "unchanged".  Will repeat TTE today to
   again eval for tamponade.  Depending on what echo shows in terms of the
   RV, will eval need for a V/Q scan to r/o PE as a cause of shock.
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  However, she did not require pressors for
   much of the day.  Will run CVVH at a 0 balance.
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology c/w malignancy.  Left sided
   effusion improved s/p pigtail placement but CT on [**9-22**] showed increased
   right sided effusion.  Only requiring NC at this time.
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  270cc serosang fluid in prev 24 hours.
   - IP following pigtail.
   - IP will also perform thoracentesis of right sided effusion.
   - ? of Pleurodesis when stable
   - Added standing bronchodilators for wheezing
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.
   - Line replaced by renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   Will re-consult urology for percutaneous nephrostomy tube for
   drainage.  [**Month (only) 51**] need anesthesia eval prior to procedure.
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   - Follow electrolytes and replete as needed
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - Will require inpt palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 125 mcg.  Also, obtained anti-TPO
   antibodies.  Need to re-check a free T4 in several days.
   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and
   ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/
   Ca gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment  and has remained
   wnl.
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure (ARF), and malignant pleural effusion. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for several days and has been receiving various treatments, including pressors, antibiotics, and dialysis.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 99 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 93/67 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 7 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 21.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.9 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 254 x 10^9/L
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 24 mg/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 237 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 1.8 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.5 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypothyroidism
* Hyperlipidemia
* ARF
* Malignant pleural effusion
* Metastatic ovarian cancer

The patient's current medications include:

* Calcium gluconate (CRRT)
* Norepinephrine
* KCl (CRRT)
* Famotidine (Pepcid)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Other medications (not specified)

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue empiric antibiotics for 5 more days
* Repeat thoracentesis of right-sided effusion
* Consider pleurodesis when stable
* Consult oncology for palliative chemotherapy
* Hold home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
* Monitor electrolytes and replete as needed
* Consult endocrinology to re-check free T4 in several days

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis
* Metabolic acidosis
* Cardiogenic shock
* Hypovolemia
* Tamponade
* Pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Respiratory failure
* Infection of the central venous catheter
* Line infection
* Tumor lysis syndrome

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is unclear.

s help.

   Hypotension: appears to have responded to albumin challenge.  After
   250cc Plasmanate, she came off the norepinephrine.  This suggests that
   optimal CVP is probably ~14+ in this patient.  I suspect that she has
   ongoing losses into her peritoneum, pleura, and subcutaneous tissue and
   will require additional volume expansion.  We have pursued colloid
   rather than crystalloid because of her anasarca.

   stenting with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1458**] (from renal). We agree that her
   hydronephrosis probably only contributes a small amount to her renal
   failure. However, we were able to keep her off dialysis for almost
   three days with only mild-moderate increases in her creatinine. I
   therefore think that a very minimal increase in renal function might
   result in her being able to be off of dialysis. I in no way believe
   that this a guaranteed result, and in fact think that it only somewhere
   in the 10, 20, or 30 percent range, which is how I discussed it with
   her and her family today.
   I spent 45 minutes today talking about this decision with the patient,
   her son, and her daughter. We talked about the fact that we don't have
   certainty about the results of treatment for her (either the planned
   stent or any potential cytotoxic therapy), and went through several
   potential ways forward, including stenting, an attempt at chemotherapy
   without stenting, etc. We also talked explicitly about potential
   adverse outcomes from the stent/anesthesia, even including respiratory
   failure and inability to get her off the vent (which I think is
   extremely unlikely but in many ways is one of the worst possible
   outcomes).
   They are able to verbalize understanding of all this and wanted to
   proceed with the plan of care we've described (attempt at stenting,
   assessment of renal response, and subsequent consideration of
   chemotherapeutic rx).
   I think that this is a reasonable way to balance the risks and benefits
   in this challenging situation.  All questions answered.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with shock of uncertain etiology, recent diagnosis of ovarian cancer, and multiple comorbidities. She is currently in the ICU and is being treated for acute renal failure, respiratory distress, and septic shock. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 112/63 mmHg. She has a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and is receiving norepinephrine to support her blood pressure. Her WBC count is elevated at 19.4, and her blood cultures have remained negative.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's shock is likely due to a combination of factors, including hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her hypotension. A colloid challenge is planned to try to improve her CVP, and if she remains on pressors, midodrine may be considered. Leucocytosis is persistent, but cultures have remained negative, and antibiotics will be discontinued. The patient's respiratory distress has improved, and she is being managed with bronchodilators and chest tube management. Acute renal failure is being treated with CVVHD, and the plan is to relieve post-renal obstruction by stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH/FT4 results suggest hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her hypotension. This needs to be monitored and treated accordingly.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is being treated with antibiotics, but the cultures have remained negative. This needs to be monitored, and the possibility of sepsis needs to be considered.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is being treated with CVVHD, and the plan is to relieve post-renal obstruction by stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy.
4. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress has improved, but she may still require bronchodilators and chest tube management.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is being treated with norepinephrine, and a colloid challenge is planned to try to improve her CVP.
6. Leucocytosis: The patient's leucocytosis is persistent, but cultures have remained negative, and antibiotics will be discontinued.
7. Anasarca: The patient has anasarca, which may be contributing to her hypotension and respiratory distress. This needs to be monitored and treated accordingly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue to treat the patient's shock with norepinephrine and a colloid challenge.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust bronchodilators and chest tube management as needed.
4. Continue to treat the patient's acute renal failure with CVVHD and consider relieving post-renal obstruction by stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy.
5. Monitor the patient's leucocytosis and consider discontinuing antibiotics if cultures remain negative.
6. Monitor the patient's anasarca and consider treating with diuretics if necessary.
7. Consider consulting with an endocrinologist to further evaluate and treat the patient's hypothyroidism.

   Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1458**] (from renal) and I just re-discussed the case. We agree
   that her hydronephrosis probably only contributes a small amount to her
   renal failure. However, we were able to keep her off dialysis for more
   than two days with only mild-moderate increases in her creatinine. I
   therefore think that a very minimal increase in renal function might
   result in her being able to be off of dialysis. I have no illusions
   that this is in any way a guaranteed result, and in fact think that it
   only somewhere in the 10, 20, or 30 percent range, which is how I
   discussed it with her and her family today.
   In complicated situations like this, it is my practice to discuss the
   situation in a lot of detail with the patient and family. I spent about
   45 minutes today talking about it with the patient, her son, and her
   daughter. We talked about the fact that we don't have certainty about
   the results of treatment for her (either the planned stent or cytotoxic
   therapy), and went through several potential ways forward. We also
   talked explicitly about potential adverse outcomes from the
   stent/anesthesia, even including respiratory failure and inability to
   get her off the vent (which I think is extremely unlikely but in many
   ways is one of the worst possible outcomes).
   They are able to verbalize understanding of all this and wanted to
   proceed with the plan of care we've described (attempt at stenting,
   assessment of renal response, and subsequent consideration of
   chemotherapeutic rx).
   I think that this is a reasonable way to balance the risks and benefits
   in this situation and would advocate that we proceed.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 58-inch tall, 107.6 kg (24-year-old) male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of shock. The patient has undergone various diagnostic tests, including ultrasound, thoracentesis, and trans-thoracic echo, which revealed pleural effusion and possible stenting. The patient has a history of allergies to oxycodone and nausea/vomiting. He has received multiple antibiotics, including Ciprofloxacin, Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), and Vancomycin. The patient is currently receiving infusions of Norepinephrine and Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) for cardiovascular support.

Physical examination reveals a patient who is overweight/obese with a diminished right radial pulse, diminished right DP pulse, and soft, distended abdomen. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 99%. His neurologic status is also stable, with purposeful movement and normal tone.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 19.4, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 254 K/uL. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 25 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock may worsen due to the presence of pleural effusion and possible stenting.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's impaired renal function may worsen due to the presence of sepsis and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the presence of pleural effusion may worsen his respiratory function.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, and the use of vasopressors may worsen his condition.
5. Infection: The patient's septic shock may lead to the development of further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic status is unstable, and the use of vasopressors may worsen his condition.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen due to the presence of sepsis and the use of anticoagulant medications.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen due to the presence of sepsis and the use of sedatives and analgesics.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications due to his septic shock, impaired renal function, and cardiovascular instability. It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and improve his outcomes.

   stenting tomorrow and possible palliative chemo on OMED.
   MICU course as below:
   74 yo F w/ Stage IV metastatic ovarian cancer, ARF on CVVH, and
   malignant pleural effusion.  Course has been complicated by
   hypotension requiring pressors (levophed).  Originally presented
   to ED [**2-22**] ARF and hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and
   HLD.
   .
   #. Hypotension/shock.  Has required Levophed for much of
   admission.  Last 2-3 days prior to leaving the MICU for the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**]
   she tolerated several hours without pressors; however, she
   received albumin or blood during these periods.   Differential
   dx for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic,
   hypovolemia.
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started
   on empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx on [**9-25**]: pt received 6
   days of zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  Line
   infections: changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line
   was d/c
ed.  Monitored PICC line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal
   insufficiency.  Consulted ID for evaluation of whether
   hypothyroidism could cause shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid
   and transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is unlikely for
   hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned because pt
   had one episode of paroxysmal a. fib on [**9-20**] and increased dose
   of synthroid may precipitate further episodes.  Will continue to
   monitor, however, this episodes appears to be isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Originally, was concerned for tamponade.
   Although they have been suboptimal studies, multiple echoes have
   only showed effusions without echocardiographic evidence of
   tamponade with one exception.  Her echo from [**9-15**] showed
   impaired fillling/tamponade physiology.  Most recent echo on [**9-24**]
   again did not show evidence of tamponade, just small effusion.
   also, echo on [**9-24**] revealed normal RV size and motion which made
   PE less likely.  Throughout her course in the MICU, have
   considered V/Q scan to r/o PE as a possible cause of hypotension
   however, given her echo findings, the pretest possibility
   remains equivocal.
   - On [**9-22**], SVV (from Vigileo) suggested intravascular depletion,
   and repleted pt with crystalloid and colloid.  However, she did
   not require pressors for much of that day.  For last few days
   prior to transfer to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**], have been running CVVH at a 0
   balance.  Gave albumin challenge again on [**9-25**] and her CVP bumped
   to 12 and was thus able to be off of leveophed for several
   hours. It appeared that she needs her CVP to be [**1-4**] to
   maintain her BP.  Goal has been to wean levophed and have
   considered transitioning to midodrine as an oral pressor.
   - At time of transfer, the etiology of her hypotension remains
   elusive.  Without an adequate explanation, team has hypothesized
   that this may be a possible paraneoplastic syndrome.
   .
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology from left c/w malignancy.
   Final cytology from right effusion still pending at time of
   transfer but pH, cell counts, gluc, prot consistent with left
   effusion and anticipate that it will also be malignant. Prior to
   first thoracentesis, pt required BiPap but upon transfer, pt has
   been satting well on only 1.5L NC for several days.
   Underwent both chest tube and pigtail placement for left sided
   effusion.  Chest tube was removed early in course of stay
   because it was extrathoracic and not draining but pigtail
   (placed by IP) continues to drain serosang fluid.  Was placed to
   water seal by IP on [**9-25**].  A repeat CT on [**9-22**] showed increased
   right sided effusion which was tapped on [**9-24**].  IP is considering
   either Pleurodesis vs pleurex when stable.  Has also used
   bronchodilators for wheezing.
   .
   #. Acute renal failure
 Persistent volume overload and
   anasarca.  Originally admitted with K of 7.8 and Cr of 7.2.
   Hyperkalemia resolved quickly (see below).  Held on dialysis for
   a few days but CVVH was started on [**9-16**] but had to be stopped
   temporarily on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line changed over the wire
   by renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH. Initial and repeat imaging
   of kidneys has showed continued right hydronephrosis.  Plan is
   to transfer from MICU ([**Hospital Ward Name **]) to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] in order to go to
   the OR with urology on [**9-26**].  Urology will place a stent in the
   right ureter.  Goal of stenting is to relieve the obstruction
   with the hope of regaining some kidney function.  Acutely on
   [**9-24**], she developed hyponatremia and hyperglycemia. Unclear
   etiology but hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate
   bath having a Na concentration of 130.  Na corrected slightly
   following initiation of insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.

   episodes of hyperglycemia during this admission.  Also, [**Name8 (MD) **] RN,

   insulin sliding scale for the elev glucose.  Initially, pt was
   hyperphosphatemic but on the day of transfer pt required

   held home Lasix and ACE-I in setting of ARF.

   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: cardiopulmonary status has been too
   tenuous for treatment during this admission.  Obtained tumor
   markers which revealed borderline high CA-125 and elevated
   CA27,29, but were overall non-specific.  Heme onc is following

   chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum.  Family has been
   supportive of continuing more aggressive means of treatment.
   Have discussed transfer to OMED when stable and off pressors.

 Was diagnosed with hypothyroidism approx 2

   Anti-TPO ab < 10.  Also, changed from oral to IV Synthroid to

   .

   .

   admission.  Last 2 days been able to tolerate long pressor free
   periods.   Differential dx for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes,
   cardiogenic, hypovolemia.
   .
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx today ([**9-25**]); pt received 6 days
   of zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  Line infections:
   changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line was d/c
ed.  Will
   monitor PICC line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal insufficiency.
   Consulted ID for evaluation of whether hypothyroidism could cause
   shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid and transitioned to IV but
   endocrinology that it is unlikely for hypothyroidism to be the cause.
   Endo also concerned because pt had one episode of paroxysmal a. fib on
   [**9-20**] and increased dose of synthroid may precipitate further episodes.
   Will continue to monitor, however, this episodes appears to be
   isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Repeat echo on [**9-24**] did not show evidence of tamponade,
   just small effusion.  RV size and motion was wnl; can consider V/Q scan
   to r/o PE as cause of hypotension however, given the echo findings
   there is a lower pretest probability
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  However, she did not require pressors for
   much of the day.  Will run CVVH at a 0 balance.  She continues to
   require levophed, can consider midodrine v more albumin.  Will attempt
   to decrease levophed as tolerated.
   - goal CVP 12-14
   .
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology from left c/w malignancy.  Left
   sided effusion improved s/p pigtail placement but CT on [**9-22**] showed
   increased right sided effusion.  Only requiring NC at this time.
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  IP following pigtail.
   - IP performed thoracentesis of right sided effusion on [**9-24**]
   - ? of Pleurodesis vs pleurex when stable
   - Added standing bronchodilators for wheezing
   - f/u cytology for r-sided studies
   .
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line replaced by
   renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   - To OR tomorrow with urology for stenting of right ureter.  Will be
   performed on [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**], cysto-suite.  Needs to be NPO after
   midnight.
   - Has been hyponatremic and hyperglycemia.  Unclear etiology but
   hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath having a Na
   concentration of 130.  Na corrected slightly following initiation of
   insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.  Also, hyperglycemia seems to
   have occurred acutely.  No prior episodes of hyperglycemia during this
   admission.  Also, [**Name8 (MD) **] RN, finger sticks are consistently lower than
   serum glucose.  Could be related to diffuse extravascular volume.
   Continue to monitor and use ISS as needed.
   - Replete phos today; can use Na-Phos for added sodium benefit
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   .
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - Will require inpt palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - Updated gyn onc resident re pt
s current condition on [**9-25**].
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 100 mcg.  Need to re-check a free
   T4 in several days.

   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   - Monitor for a. fib
   - appreciate endocrine recs
   .
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and
   ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/
   Ca gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment  and has remained
   wnl.
   .
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a complex medical history, including metastatic ovarian cancer, acute renal failure, and bilateral pleural effusions. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has required multiple interventions, including pressors, dialysis, and thoracentesis.

The patient's hypotension and shock remain unexplained, despite multiple differential diagnoses, including sepsis, metabolic causes, cardiogenic, and hypovolemia. The patient has been on empiric antibiotics for suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia, but the line infections have been ruled out.

The patient's acute renal failure is significant, with ongoing volume overload and anasarca. The patient has been on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) since day 10, but the treatment has been complicated by poor access and the need for repeated line changes.

The patient's hyperkalemia has resolved, but she remains at risk for hyperglycemia and hyperphosphatemia. The patient has been treated with insulin sliding scale and phosphorus repletion, and her electrolyte levels are being closely monitored.

The patient's metastatic ovarian cancer is being managed with palliative chemotherapy, and she is expected to require inpatient treatment. The patient's code status is full code, and she has been advised to be NPO after midnight for her upcoming ureteral stenting procedure.

The patient's hypothyroidism is being managed with levothyroxine, and her thyroid function tests are being monitored. The patient's hyperlipidemia is being treated with a statin, and her lipid levels are being monitored.

The patient's ICU care includes regular diet, sliding scale insulin, and prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcers. The patient's lines include a dialysis catheter and a PICC line, and she is being monitored for potential complications.

The patient's disposition is to be transferred to the hospital ward for further management and treatment.

   74F with newly diagnosed metastatic ovarian cancer on pressors and [**Hospital 1460**]
   transferred from west to [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**] ICU for ureteral stenting and
   possible palliative chemo.  Originally presented to ED [**2-22**] ARF and
   hyperkalemia.  PMH includes hypothyroidism and HLD.
   .
   #. Hypotension and shock.  Has required Levophed for much of
   admission.  Last 2 days been able to tolerate long pressor free
   periods.   Differential dx for shock includes sepsis, metabolic causes,
   cardiogenic, hypovolemia.
   .
   - [**Name (NI) 1064**] pt has a leukocytosis but has been afebrile.  Started on
   empiric abx to cover for HAP.  D/c abx today ([**9-25**]); pt received 6 days
   of zosyn, 9 days of cipro, and 4 days of vanc.  Line infections:
   changed HD cath over the wire on [**9-23**] and art line was d/c
ed.  Will
   monitor PICC line for signs of infection.
   - Metabolic- [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim was wnl so likely not adrenal insufficiency.
   Will check AM cortisol tomorrow morning. Consulted ID for evaluation of
   whether hypothyroidism could cause shock.  Increased dose of Synthroid
   and transitioned to IV but endocrinology that it is unlikely for
   hypothyroidism to be the cause. Endo also concerned because pt had one
   episode of paroxysmal a. fib on [**9-20**] and increased dose of synthroid
   may precipitate further episodes.  Will continue to monitor, however,
   this episodes appears to be isolated.
   - Cardiogenic-  Repeat echo on [**9-24**] did not show evidence of tamponade,
   just small effusion.  RV size and motion was wnl; can consider V/Q scan
   to r/o PE as cause of hypotension however, given the echo findings
   there is a lower pretest probability
   - On [**9-22**], SVV suggested intravascular depletion, and repleted pt with
   crystalloid and colloid.  However, she did not require pressors for
   much of the day.  Will run CVVH at a 0 balance.  She continues to
   require levophed, can consider midodrine v more albumin.  Will attempt
   to decrease levophed as tolerated.
   - goal CVP 12-14
   .
   # Bilat pleural effusions, cytology from left c/w malignancy.  Left
   sided effusion improved s/p pigtail placement but CT on [**9-22**] showed
   increased right sided effusion.  Only requiring NC at this time.
   - Pigtail cath draining well.  IP following pigtail.
   CT scan when possible to assess for progression of disease.
   - IP performed thoracentesis of right sided effusion on [**9-24**]
   - Pleurodesis vs pleurex when stable
   - Added standing bronchodilators for wheezing
   - f/u cytology for r-sided studies
   .
   #. Acute renal failure
 Significant vol overload and anasarca.  CVVH
   started on [**9-16**] and stopped on [**9-20**] [**2-22**] poor access.  Line replaced by
   renal on [**9-23**] and restarted CVVH.
   - Repeat imaging of kidneys showed unchanged right hydronephrosis.
   - To OR today with urology for stenting of right ureter.  Will be
   performed on [**Hospital Ward Name 1437**], cysto-suite.  Needs to be NPO after midnight.
   Patient is not candidate for percutaneous nephrostomy tube, due to
   anasarca; it will still need MAC.
   - Has been hyponatremic and hyperglycemia.  Unclear etiology but
   hyponatremia may be related to the ultrafiltrate bath having a Na
   concentration of 130.  Na corrected slightly following initiation of
   insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.  Also, hyperglycemia seems to
   have occurred acutely.  No prior episodes of hyperglycemia during this
   admission.  Also, [**Name8 (MD) **] RN, finger sticks are consistently lower than
   serum glucose.  Could be related to diffuse extravascular volume.
   Continue to monitor and use ISS as needed.
   - Replete phos today; can use Na-Phos for added sodium benefit
   - holding home Lasix and ACE-I in ARF
   .
   # Metastatic ovarian cancer: at this time, not stable for treatment
   - Will require inpt palliative chemotherapy, most likely carboplatinum
   - When off pressors, can be transferred to OMED
   - Onc would prefer chest tube to be out prior to chemotherapy
   - Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis syndrome
   - Updated gyn onc resident re pt
s current condition on [**9-25**].
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism
 Consulted endocrinology to help elucidate if
   hypothyroidism could be cause of persistent hypotension.  Preliminary
   thought is no, but increased dose to 100 mcg.  Need to re-check a free
   T4 in several days.
   - Anti-TPO ab < 10
   - Changed from oral to IV to ensure proper absorption
   - Monitor for a. fib
   - appreciate endocrine recs
   .
   #. Hyperkalemia, resolved: Most likely due to worsening renal function,
   esp in setting of the medications she was taking, including Lasix and
   ACE-I. Pt had K 7.8 on arrival to ED, without ECG changes. Treated w/
   Ca gluconate, insulin / dextrose, albuterol nebs, and Kayexelate.
   Potassium has appropriately responded to treatment  and has remained
   wnl.
   .
   #. Hyperlipidemia - cont home statin dose
   .
   ICU Care
